title-group.article-title: Advanced treatment of the output-stream of biological leachate treatment by appropriate combination of coagulation/flocculation and oxidation

article-meta.aff: 1School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Zhang Haiying, School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, 120 Caobao Street, Shanghai, China Email: juli506@126.com

abstract.p: An integrated technique consisting of oxidation and coagulation–flocculation processes was investigated in order to provide an effective method for the treatment of biologically pre-treated leachate and to reduce pollutants to values under the limit required for discharging to the receiving waters. Leachate containing 985 mg L−1 chemical oxygen demand (COD) was treated by using oxidation with NaClO, coagulation/flocculation with aluminium sulfate (alum) or poly-ferric sulfate (PFS) as well as combined pre-oxidation followed by coagulation/flocculation. Oxidation resulted in the removal of COD and colour up to 78.9 and 88.4%, respectively, however residual COD values were over 200 mg L−1 even under intensive experimental conditions (high dosage of NaClO and prolonged oxidation time). Coagulation with PFS was found to be more efficient in comparison with alum, and it yielded a residual COD of 184 mg L−1 the optimum coagulation conditions (polyacrylamide (PAM) 5 mg L−1, PFS 30 mg L−1, pH 6, reaction time 20 min). The combined process involving oxidation followed by coagulation/flocculation with PFS resulted in residual COD values lower than 100 mg L−1 the following conditions: 40–60 min pre-oxidation with 30 mg L−1 NaClO followed by coagulation with 200–250 mg L−1. Hence, pre-oxidation with NaClO followed by coagulation with PFS was recommended for removal of biologically-treated substances from the biologically-treated or stabilized leachate.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Leachate, generated as a consequence of rainwater percolation through waste materials, chemical biological processes in waste and the inherent water content of waste (Ebru, 2004), is characterized by high chemical oxygen demand (COD), colour and suspended solids (SS) (Rivas et al., 2003). Leachate contains a large amount of organic matter, ammonia-nitrogen, heavy metals, chlorinated organic and inorganic salts, which, if not treated properly, may cause severe contamination to the environment and also threaten human health. Therefore, it is necessary to treat the leachate properly (Zhang and Ding, 2009). Generally, leachate requires primary, secondary and advanced treatment prior to discharging to the receiving waters (Yu et al., 2005). Leachate recirculation, biological and physicochemical treatment processes are often used to treat landfill leachate, it seems to need a combination of two or more technologies to reduce pollutants to below the limit required for discharging to the receiving waters (Galvez et al., 2005; Pi et al., 2009; Zamora et al., 2000).

The implementation of the most appropriate technique for the treatment of leachate depends on the specific characteristics of the leachate. Biological processes are quite effective in eliminating its organic loading in the effluent when applied to relatively freshly produced leachate (Jerry et al., 2004; Li et al., 2008). However, biologically treated leachate needs advanced treatment as it includes inorganic pollutants such as ammonia, cyanogen, sulfocyan, heterocyclic compounds and polycyclic aromatic compounds such as phenol, oils, naphthalene, pyridine, quinoline and anthracites, which are difficult to degrade biologically under aerobic conditions (Mustafa et al., 2005).

Physical–chemical methods are effective for the treatment of low-strength leachate after biological treatment (Ntampou et al., 2006). Coagulation/flocculation is a relatively simple technique that may be employed successfully for the treatment of biologically-treated leachate (Zhang and Ding, 2009). However, this method may result in moderate removals of COD content, excessive sludge production and an increase of aluminium or iron concentrations in the effluent (Trebouet et al., 2001). Thus, coagulation/flocculation is often used as a post-treatment technique for the partially stabilized leachate.

Several researchers have investigated the efficiency of oxidation for the treatment of landfill leachate (Wu et al., 2004). The chemical oxidation makes it possible for the transformation of recalcitrant substances into biodegradable products, or even to CO2. Oxidation is not considered as very effective due to the complexity of leachate composition, and the produced intermediate oxidation products could also raise the toxicity of the resulting effluent (Silva et al., 2004). Combined processes involving oxidation and coagulation were also reported in advanced treatment of leachate (Chen, 2008), but the existing technologies were costly (Luo et al., 2010).

The objective of the present study was to investigate the integrated technique for the treatment of stabilized or biologically treated leachate by a combination of oxidation and coagulation/flocculation. Three treatment processes were investigated: oxidation with NaClO; coagulation/flocculation with aluminium sulfate (alum) or poly-ferric sulfate (PFS); pre-oxidation followed by coagulation/flocculation. Various treatment conditions were investigated for each process to determine the optimum conditions for removal of COD, colour and SS, aiming to yield effluent quality that was lower than the limit of the second grade described in Integrated Wastewater Discharge Standard (GB8979-1996), namely COD lower than 100 mg L−1, colour lower than 50 times, SS lower than 150 mg L−1, and pH between 6 and 9.

sec.title: Leachate characterization
sec.p: Leachate samples were collected from the effluent pond of the biological treatment process for leachate from the municipal solid waste incineration plant. Leachate was generated during the storage of municipal solid waste to be incinerated. About 300–400 m3 day−1 of biologically treated leachate are transferred to the main wastewater treatment plant for further treatment. Leachate samples were collected in 20 L plastic carboys, transported to the laboratory and stored at 4°C. All samples were characterized for COD, colour, suspended solid concentration (SS) and pH using standard dichromate reflux (GB11914-89), multiple dilution and drying method, and with pH meter, respectively. Colour was measured using the dilution method, and its unit is times. For example, colour 50 times means that its concentration was diluted to 1/50 with water, when the diluted solution has the same colour with pure water. The corresponding main physicochemical parameters of the samples were: COD = 985 mg L−1, biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)/COD = 0.19, colour = 240 times, SS = 569 mg L−1, pH = 8.15. Apparently, the leachate may be classified as stabilized leachate with high non-biodegradable organic content.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The chemicals used in this experiment included sodium hypochlorite (NaClO solution, available chlorine >5.2%), alum, PFS and PAM. Coagulation/flocculation and oxidation studies were performed using a mixer (JJ-4) with six beakers of 1 L volume. The oxidation process consisted of three stages: 1-min fast stirring (500 rpm); slow stirring (100 rpm) for 20 min in determination of the optimum NaClO dosage and for 0, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60 and 90 min, respectively in determination of the optimum oxidation time; and finally settling for 30 min. The coagulation process also consisted of three stages: 1-min fast stirring (500 rpm) to mix up the leachate and chemicals, slow stirring (100 rpm) for 15, 20 and 25 min, respectively to ensure full reaction and finally settling for 30 min. After the settling stage in both processes, the supernatant was characterized for COD, colour, SS and pH.

Determination of the optimum conditions for oxidation with NaClO was performed based on the removal efficiency as a function of NaClO dosages (5, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 mL L−1), and removal efficiency as a function of oxidation times (0, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60 and 90 min). A four-factor-three-level orthogonal test was designed to determine the optimal conditions for coagulation/flocculation using alum + PAM and PFS + PAM, respectively. Four factors were dosage of PFS or alum, dosage of PAM, pH, and reaction time (Table 1), and the control indexes are removal efficiency of COD, colour and SS.

caption.p: Factors and levels of orthogonal tests for coagulation-flocculation

sec.p: The combined processing occurred by the pre-oxidation with 30 mL L−1 NaClO for 0, 20, 40 and 60 min, respectively, followed by coagulation with PFS for 20 min. Dosage of PFS was varied between 5 and 40 mg L−1 and pH was adjusted to 6 at the fast stirring stage. During the slow stirring stage 5 mg L−1 PAM was added aiming to improve the settling characteristics and to enhance reduction of the produced sludge volume. Oxidation time and coagulation time throughout the manuscript refer to the time of slow stirring in the processes.

sec.title: Oxidation
sec.p: The correlation between removal efficiency of COD, colour, SS and dosage of NaClO (Figure 1) indicated that removal efficiency reached the maximum value (58.7%) at 30 mL L−1 for COD, while it increased steadily with increasing dosage up to 50 mL L−1 for colour and SS. COD removal may be attributed to composition of the biologically-treated leachate which contains a significant fraction of recalcitrant and high molecular weight organic substances (Zamora et al., 2000). With increasing dosage to 50 mL L−1, the initial yellow colour of the leachate, which is due to the existence of humic substances, became light yellow. Colour reduction can be mainly attributed to the destruction of carbon-double bonds in the chromophoric body, yielding such bleached products as aliphatic acids, ketones and aldehydes (Gottschalk et al., 2000). Oxidation has been applied as a final polishing step of coloured wastewaters (Koch et al., 2002) to reduce the colour. Dosages of 20, 30 and 40 mL L−1 were chosen to study the influence of reaction time on removal efficiency of COD, colour and SS of the leachate.

caption.p: Reduction of COD, colour and SS as a function of NaClO dosage during the oxidation experiments.

sec.p: The removal efficiencies as a function of oxidation time are shown in Figure 2. It was shown that removal efficiency of COD, colour and SS increased steadily with increasing reaction time. During the initial reaction stage (up to 20 min) COD removal efficiency reached up to 54.7, 58.7 and 57.6%, respectively (Figure 2(a)). After extended oxidation (90 min), COD values decreased to 238, 208 and 227 mg L−1, respectively, corresponding to removal efficiencies of 75.8, 78.9 and 77%, respectively. Ntampou et al. (2006) reported COD removal rates up to 63% after 1 h oxidation. This can be attributed to the fact that oxidation of easily degradable organics occurred during the short reaction times, while the reaction rate decreased due to the decrease of the reactive substances and the existence of lower-reactivity by-products (aldehydes, ketones and organic acids) generated in the initial oxidation stage and the presence of recalcitrant substances (Gottschalk et al., 2000).

caption.p: Reduction of (a) COD, (b) colour and (c) SS as well as (d) final pH as a function of oxidation time, during oxidation.

sec.p: Figure 2(b) showed a significant de-colorization of 59, 83 and 88.4% for the three dosages, indicating the presence of residual non-chromophoric compounds which could not be further oxidized by NaClO at the present experimental conditions. Rivas et al. (2003) and Silva et al. (2004) reported a reduction of up to 95% of colour during oxidation. In addition, the de-colorization rate was very high during the initial 20 min, corresponding to removal efficiencies of 54.5, 77.3 and 86.4%, respectively. Consequently, de-coloration reactions took place with a high rate in the initial reaction time and they were almost completed during the initial 30 min. Monje-Ramirez and Orta de Velasquez (2004) also reported that the colour removal rate was almost two orders of magnitude faster that COD removal. Figure 2(c) showed that removal efficiencies of SS reached up to 65, 88 and 90.5% after 90 min oxidation for dosages of 20, 30 and 40 mg L−1, respectively. Effluent pH as a function of reaction time (Figure 2(d)) showed a drop from 8.32 to 7.30 for 20 mL L−1, a drop from 8.43 to 6.50 for 30 mL L−1 and a decrease from 8.51 to 7.3 for 40 mL L−1. This can be attributed to the generation of acidic secondary by-products during oxidation. The pH increased again with increasing reaction time which can be attributed to the stripping of carbon dioxide and volatile fatty acids (Wu et al., 2004).

It was clear from the above analysis that the three dosages yielded similar removal efficiency after 60 min oxidation for COD (75.8% for 20 mL L−1, 78.9% for 30 mL L−1 and 77% for 40 mL L−1). The removal of colour was relatively constant after 30 min oxidation, corresponding to around 57.7% for 20 mL L−1, 81.4% for 30 mL L−1 and 87.2% for 40 mL L−1. Quite similar to the de-colorization efficiency, removal of SS reached constant values after 30 min reaction, corresponding to around 59% for 20 mL L−1, 84% for 30 mL L−1 and 85% for 40 mL L−1. However, the effluent COD did not meet the requirements of the standard GB8979 (1996), even at the intensive conditions with the optimum NaClO dosage (30 mL L−1) and extended oxidation time (up to 90 min), which made it necessary for a combined treatment of oxidation with coagulation/flocculation.

sec.title: Coagulation/flocculation analysis
sec.p: Based on the orthogonal test analysis taking effluent COD or SS removal efficiency as the control index (Figure 3(a) and (c)), the influence of the four factors on effluent COD and SS followed the decreasing sequence of alum dosage > PAM dosage > pH > reaction time. The optimal coagulation conditions for removal of COD and SS were: PAM dosage of 5 mg L−1, alum dosage of 750 mg L−1, pH of 7 and reaction time of 25 min for the former; and PAM dosage of 7 mg L−1, alum dosage of 875 mg L−1, pH of 7 and reaction time of 20 min for the latter. Orthogonal analysis taking effluent colour removal efficiency as the control index (Figure 3 (b)), showed that influence of the four factors followed the decreasing sequence of alum dosage > pH > reaction time ≈ PAM dosage. The optimal coagulation condition for removal of colour was: PAM dosage of 5 or 3 mg L−1 alum dosage of 750 mg L−1, pH of 7 and reaction time of 20 min. Apparently, alum dosage had the most significant influence on the removal efficiency of COD, colour and SS, whereas reaction time had the minimal influence. Based on orthogonal analysis for PAM and alum, the optimum coagulation-flocculation conditions were: PAM dosage of 5 mg L−1, alum dosage of 750 mg L−1, pH of 7 and reaction time of 20 min. Removal efficiency at the optimal conditions was 49.6% for COD, 78.1% for colour and 68.2% for SS, and the corresponding effluent quality was: COD 496 mg L−1, SS 181 mg L−1, colour 53 times. The result indicated that alum was inefficient in removing COD from the biologically-treated leachate. It may be caused by the existence of poly-nuclear hydrolysis products ((Al13O4(OH)24)7+), which can be de-polymerized in the presence of natural organic matter, thus resulting in a lower removal efficiency of alum (Duan and Gregory, 2003).

caption.p: Orthogonal test analysis for alum and PAM taking removal efficiency of (a) COD, (b) colour and (c) SS as the control index, respectively.

sec.p: Orthogonal test analysis for coagulation/flocculation with PFS and PAM (Figure 4) showed that the significance of the four factors followed the decreasing sequence of PFS dosage > PAM dosage ≈ pH > reaction time for COD, PFS dosage > PAM dosage > pH ≈ reaction time for colour, and PFS dosage > pH > PAM dosage > reaction time for SS. The optimal conditions were: PAM dosage of 5 mg L−1, PFS dosage of 30 mg L−1, pH of 6 and reaction time of 20 min for removal of COD and SS; PAM dosage of 5 mg L−1, PFS dosage of 30 mg L−1, pH of 6 and reaction time of 25 min for removal of colour. It was indicated that PFS dosage had the most significant influence on treatment efficiency of the leachate, while reaction time had the minimal influence on it, quite similar to the coagulation/flocculation process with alum and PAM. Hence, the optimal conditions were PAM dosage of 5 mg L−1, PFS dosage of 30 mg L−1, pH of 6 and reaction time of 20 min for coagulation with PFS. Removal efficiency at the optimal condition was 81.3% for COD, 89.2% for colour and 86.7% for SS, and the effluent quality was: COD 184 mg L−1, colour 26 times and SS 76 mg L−1.

caption.p: Orthogonal test analysis for PFS and PAM taking removal efficiency of (a) COD, (b) colour and (c) SS as the control index, respectively.

sec.p:
Removal of pollutants through coagulation with PFS or alum can be attributed to the fact that the optimum coagulant dosage produced consistent flocs with a good structure. While the produced flocs are small and influence sludge setting velocity for a lower dosage, and re-stability occurs for a dosage over the optimum value, resulting to less removal of pollutants. Effluent pH was higher than that of the coagulation solution, which should be caused by reaction of [

with pollutants (Yan et al., 2008). The results also showed that the chemical coagulation/flocculation process was pH dependent. At low pH, H competes with metal hydrolysis products for organic ligands, which resulted in poor removal efficiency and some of the produced organic acids will not precipitate. At a higher pH, hydroxide ions compete with organic compounds for metal adsorption sites and co-precipitation occurs (Xue et al., 2005).

Summarizing the aforementioned results, coagulation/flocculation of the biologically-treated leachate by using PFS yielded more efficient de-colorization and removal of COD and SS at the optimum conditions than in the case of coagulation with alum and oxidation with NaClO. However, the effluent COD exceeded the standard GB8979 (1996) even at the optimum conditions, and thus it required further processing. To achieve better removal of the pollutants, combined treatment involving pre-oxidation with NaClO followed by coagulation with PFS was investigated.

sec.title: Combined treatment by oxidation followed by coagulation/flocculation
sec.p: The pre-oxidized leachate samples were used to investigate the influence of oxidation on the efficiency of the subsequent coagulation/flocculation in comparison with treatment efficiency of PFS for biologically treated leachate. As SS and the colour of the pre-oxidized leachate met requirement of the secondary standard GB8979 (1996), only COD removal efficiency was analysed in assessing efficiency of the combined treatment process.

COD reduction as a function of PFS dosage and pre-oxidation duration for pre-oxidized leachate samples is presented in Figure 5. As shown, the final COD values of leachate first decreased and then increased with increasing PFS dosage, reaching the minimal values at 300, 250, 250 and 200 mL L−1 for leachate pre-oxidized for 0, 20, 40 and 60 min, respectively, corresponding to effluent COD of 184, 109, 92 and 89 mg L−1. Thus it indicated that application of pre-oxidation reduced the required amount of PFS dosage to achieve the maximum removal efficiency of COD. This can be attributed to the decrease of colloidal charge density of humic substances during oxidation (Farvardin and Collins, 1989). The lowest values were found for samples pre-oxidized for 40 or 60 min, and 40 or 60 min pre-oxidization yielded similar final COD in the combined treatment. Pre-oxidation for 40 or 60 min reduced final COD to below 100 mg L−1 at the optimum dosages, which was caused by influence of pre-oxidation on electrostatic interactions between the coagulant flocs and the small molecular acidic organic generated during the pre-oxidation process (Tanaka et al., 2001). Consequently, combined treatment by oxidation with NaClO followed by coagulation with PFS yielded final COD values lower than limit of the secondary standard GB8979 (1996) for the biologically treated leachate samples.

caption.p: COD reduction as a function of PFS dosage for leachate pre-oxidized for different times.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Oxidation and coagulation/flocculation processes were investigated for advanced processing of biologically treated leachate. The process of oxidation yielded removal efficiency up to 78.9% for COD, 88.4% for colour and 90.5% for SS, corresponding to final COD 208 mg L−1, colour 28 times and SS 54 mg L−1. However, final COD values were over 200 mg L−1 even under intensive experimental conditions; namely a high dosage of NaClO and prolonged oxidation time.

Coagulation/flocculation involved processing with alum and PFS at various dosages, pH and for varied reaction time. PFS was proved to be more efficient in removing pollutants than alum. The optimal conditions for PFS (PAM dosage of 5 mg L−1 PFS dosage of 30 mg L−1, pH of 6 and reaction time of 20 min) yielded removal efficiency of 81.3% for COD, 89.2% for colour and 86.7% for SS, corresponding to the final COD 184 mg L−1, colour 26 times and SS 76 mg L−1. However, the effluent COD exceeded the secondary standard GB8979 (1996) required for discharging to the waters.

The combined treatment process involving oxidation followed by coagulation/flocculation with PFS resulted in a significant reduction of COD to lower than 100 mg L−1 using 40–60 min pre-oxidation with 30 mL L−1 NaClO followed by coagulation with 200–250 mg L−1 PFS. It is recommended for advanced treatment of biologically-treated leachate.

ack.p: We thank the Leading Academic Discipline Project of Shanghai Municipal Education Commission under the project number J51502. We also thank laboratory technicians of the Department of Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology for assisting with the experimental work
